summary: Webpack bundling of workflow code fails when transitive dependencies pull in Node.js built-in modules or native code. The bundler incorrectly tries to resolve these modules, causing build failures even when they're not actually used at runtime.
userImpact: Users cannot bundle workflow code that transitively depends on packages that use Node.js built-ins or native code, blocking legitimate use cases with monorepos and certain dependencies.
rootCause: Webpack defaults to browser target and tries to resolve all imported modules, including Node.js built-ins and native packages that aren't actually needed in the workflow sandbox context.
proposedFix: Add `target: 'node'` to webpack config, allow users to specify ignored modules via `BundleOptions.ignoreModules`, or provide webpack config override hooks. Stub modules approach used successfully for `assert` could be extended.
workaround: Import specific utilities directly rather than through barrel exports (e.g., import from `../api/models` instead of `../api/index`), though this is impractical at scale.
resolutionDetails: Implemented ignoreModules configuration option in BundleOptions to allow users to exclude problematic transitive dependencies from bundling.
keyQuote: Webpack is sometime unable to determine that the external package is not actually required at runtime, and will therefore try to load it, causing a build failure.
